Maiestie hath ben, is, and ought to be answeared of her Maiesties customes and subsidies of the sayde karsies, accordyng to the number of peeces, or whole karsies, and not accordyng to the quantitie or number of yardes, in euery of the sayde karsies conteyned: and where certaine marchaunt strangers, and others, vsing the trade of transporting karsies by way of marchaundize beyonde the seas, haue of late deuised and procured to haue karsies made of much greater lengthes, as of xxv. and xxvi. yardes and more, and intende, as it may be wel geathered, to haue them made of greater length from tyme to time, by whiche policie they doo not only deceiue the Queenes Maiestie of one thirde part of her customes and subsidies due for the same karsies, for that euery two karsies nowe paying custome but for two karsies, do by the sayde meane contayne more then three karsies, that were wont to yeelde custome for three karsies: but also the poore Artificers, Weauers, and other woorkemen, occupying making of the sayde karsies, are sicle or nothyng more consydered in theyr wages for making of the sayde long karsies: Moreouer, the marchauntes of Englande vsing the trade of bying the sayde vsuall ordinarie sortes, or others, are easely eaten vp and vndonne by the sayde straungers, for that the sayde straungers conueying by deceipte so muche of her Maiesties custome, are able by selling beyonde the seas vnder the Englishe marchauntes price, to driue all the Englishe marchauntes to losse, and Englishe subiectes makers of ordinarie karsies, are by the sayde subtyle aduauntage dryuen from theyr trade, and lykely to be
shortly enforced to chaunge their Loumes, Misles, and other instrumentes, for that no other sort of karsies, in respect of the gayne in deceiuing her Maiestie, are likely to be vsually bought, which newe deuise is to the great defraudyng of her Maiestie, to the vndoing of her subiectes, the Englishe marchauntes, and of the Clothiers vsing the makyng of karsies, and of an infinite number of poore families susteyned by woorkemanship about the same.

Be it therefore enacted by the Queenes highnesse, the Lordes Spirituall and Temporall, and the Commons in this present Parliament assembled, that from and after the feast of Saint Bartholomewe the Apostle next ensuing, it shal not be lawfull for any person or persons, vsing, or that shall vse the trade of makyng of karsies, to make or cause to be made any karsies of the sorte called ordinarie karsies, or any sortyng karsies, or any other karsies, by what name or names so euer they be called, aboue the length of eyghteene yardes at the moste, to be measured by yarde and ynche, beyng redy made: but that all karsies shalbe made of the sayde vsuall lengthes, and accordyng to the proportion of weyght limitted by the statute in that behalfe made and prouided in the fourth and fyfth yeeres of the raignes of the late kyng Philip and Queene Marie, vppon payne that euery person or persons, that shal make, or cause to be made, any suche karsie or karsies of more or greater length then eyghteene yardes, shall forfayte for euery suche karsie .xl. s. the one moytie whereof shalbe to the Queenes Maiestie, her heyres and successours, and the other moytie to hym or them that wyl sue for the same, by byll, plaint, or information, in any of the Queenes Maiesties Courtes of Recorde, wherein no essoigne, protection, or wager of lawe, for the defendaunt shalbe admitted or allowed.

Prouided, that yf any karsie or karsies beyng purposely made to contayne eyghteene yardes in length, and no more, shall by occasion happen to contayne aboue eyghteene yardes, and being vnder nineteene yardes in length, that the maker or makers of any suche karsie or karseies, shall not incurre the penaltie aboue conteyned, any thing before mentioned to the contrary, notwithstandyng.

div.head: ❧ An Acte for the continuation, explanation, perfiting, and enlarging of diuers statutes. Chapter. xj.
div.p:
WHere in the parliament holden vppon prorogation at Westminster the fourth day of Februarie, in the .xxiiii. yere of the raigne of the late kyng Henry the eyght, one acte was there made, entituled, An acte to continue, and renew the act made agaynst kylling of Calues: and one other acte entituled, An acte agaynst kyllyng of young beastes, called waynlings. And where in the session of a Parliament ended at Westminster in the first day of Februarie, in the fourth yere of the raigne of our late soueraigne Lorde kyng Edwarde the sixth, one acte was made concernyng the buying and sellyng of rother beastes: and also one other acte was then and there lykewyse made, entituled, An acte for the buying and sellyng of butter and cheese. And where also an acte was made in the first session of the Parliament, holden in the fyfth yere of the Queenes Maiesties raigne, entituled, An acte for the maintenaunce and encrease of Tyllage. And where also in the Parliament begunne at Westminster in the .xxiii. day of Ianuary in the firste yere of the raigne of the Queenes Maiestie that nowe is, and there continued by prorogation vntyll the dissolution thereof, one acte was then and there made, entituled, An acte for the preseruation of spawne and frye of fyshe. And where also in the first session of the Parliament begunne and holden at Westminster, in the fyfth yere of the raigne of our soueraigne Lady the Queenes Maiestie that nowe is, and from thence continued by prorogation vntyll the dissolution thereof, one acte
was then and there made, entituled, An acte for the auoydyng of diuers forrayne wares, made by handycraftes men beyond the seas: and one other acte, entituled, An acte for the punishment of suche persons as shoulde procure or commit any wylfull periurie, whiche actes were limited to endure to thende of the next Parliament. And where also in the last session of the same Parliament holden by prorogation at Westminster, in the eyght yere of the raigne of the Queenes most excellent Maiestie that nowe is, one acte was then and there made, entituled, An acte for Bowyers, and the prices of bowes, and was made to continue to thend of the first session of the next Parliament: and also one other acte was then made, entituled, An acte for the preseruation of grayne: All whiche seuerall actes and statutes were made to continue, but for certayne tymes: and all whiche actes made in the sayde fourth yere of kyng Edwarde the sixth, and in the sayd first, fyfth, and eyght yeres of the Queenes Maiesties raigne, were at the last Parliament holden at Westminster the seconde day of Apryll, in the thirteenth yeere of the raigne of our sayd soueraigne Lady the Queenes Maiestie, made to continue and stande in force vnto thende of the next Parliament then next folowyng. And where also in the Parliament begunne and holden at Westminster the seconde day of Apryll, in the thirteenth yere of the raigne of our sayde soueraigne Lady the Queene, one acte and statute was then and there made, for the auoydyng and abolishing of faigned, couenous, and fraudulent feoffamentes, gyftes, grauntes, alienations, conueyaunces, bondes, suites, iudgementes, and executions, entituled, An acte agaynst fraudulent deedes, gyftes, grauntes, alienations, &c. whiche acte and statute was then made to endure vnto thende of the first session of the next Parliament, as by the sayde acte more playnely wyll appeare. And where also in the saide Parliament begunne and holden at Westminster the sayde seconde day of Apryll, there was also one other acte and statute made for the auoydyng of some leasses in certayne cases to be made of Ecclesiasticall promotions with cure, entituled, An acte touchyng leasses of benefices, and other Ecclesiasticall lyuinges with cure, whiche acte was lykewyse made to continue to thende of the next Parliament. And where also there was one other acte and statute made in the sayde Parliament, begunne and holden at Westminster the sayde seconde daye of Apryll, in the sayde thirteenth yeere, entituled, An acte that
purueyours may take grayne, corne, or victualles within fiue miles of Cambridge and Oxforde in certayne cases, whiche acte was made lykewyse to continue to the last day of the next Parliament.

And where in the statute made in the thirteenth yeere of the Queenes Maiesties raigne, entituled, An acte for the reuiuyng and continuaunce of certayne statutes, is conteyned one prouiso, that the sayde acte concernyng the auoydyng of forren wares made by handycraftes men beyonde the seas, or any clause, article, or meanyng therein conteyned, shoulde not in any wyse extende or be preiudicial to any entercourse, or treatise of any entercourse then standyng in force, had, or made betweene the progenitours of the Queenes Maiestie, or her hyghnesse, and any others. Nowe for good consyderations, and specially that straungers may not be at libertie, and the Queenes Maiesties naturall subiectes restrained: be it enacted that the sayde prouiso, and euery clause, article, and matter therein conteyned, shall from hencefoorth be repelled, and vtterly voyde.

Prouided also, and be it enacted, that these woordes (so soone as it, or any part thereof, shall come to any possession or vse aboue forbidden, or) whiche woordes are conteyned in the sayde statute made in the sayde thirteenth yeere, touchyng leasses of benefices, and other ecclesiasticall liuinges with cure, shall not be reuiued by this acte, but remaine discontinued, and shal from hencefoorth be omitted out of the sayde acte, any thyng in the sayde acte, or in this acte to the contrary, notwithstandyng.

And where sundry euyll disposed persons, haue defrauded the true meanyng of the sayde last mentioned statute, made in the sayde xiii. yeere, by bondes and couenauntes of suffering other persons to enioy ecclesiasticall liuinges, and the fruites thereof, for that suche bondes and couenauntes are not in lawe taken to be leasses, although in deede they amount to as muche: be it therefore enacted, that all bondes, contractes, promises, and couenauntes, hereafter to be made for suffering or permitting any person to enioy any benefice, or ecclesiasticall promotion with cure, or to take profites or fruites thereof, other then such bondes and couenauntes, as shalbe made for assuraunce of any lease heretofore made, shalbe to all intentes and purposes adiudged of suche force and validitie, and not otherwyse, as leasses by the same persons made of suche benefices and ecclesiasticall promotions with cure.

And be it further declared and enacted, that all leasses, bondes, promises, and couenauntes of and concernyng benefices and ecclesiasticall liuinges with cure, to be made by any curate, shalbe of no other, nor better force, validitie, or continuaunce, then yf the same had ben made by the beneficed person him self, that dimised, or shall dimise the same to any suche Curate.

And where in one other acte made in the said thirteenth yeere, entituled, An acte agaynst fraudulent gyftes, to the intent to defeate dilapidations of ecclesiasticall liuinges, and for leasses to be graunted by Collegiat Churches, there is one braunch to auoyde certayne leasses to be made by maisters and fellowes of Colledges, Deanes and Chapters of Cathedral or Collegiat Churches, maisters or gardians of any Hospitall, or by any Parson, Vicar, or any other hauyng any spirituall or ecclesiasticall liuing: be it enacted, that the sayde braunche, nor any thing therein conteyned, shall not extende to any graunt, assuraunce, or lease of any houses belongyng to any the persons or bodyes politique or corporate aforesayde, nor to any groundes to suche houses apparteynyng, whiche houses be situate in any Citie, Borough, Towne corporate, or market Towne, or the suburbes of any of them, but that al such houses and groundes may be graunted, dimised, and assured, as by the lawes of this Realme, and the seuerall statutes of the sayde Colledges, Cathedrall Churches and Hospitalles, they lawefully myght haue benne before the makyng of the sayd statute, or lawfully myght be, yf the sayde statute were not, so alway that suche house be not the Capitall or dwellyng house vsed for the habitation of the persons abouesayde, nor haue grounde to the same belongyng, aboue the quantitie of tenne acres, any thyng in the sayde acte to the contrary, notwithstandyng.

And be it further enacted, that all summes of money hereafter to be recouered, for, or in name of dilapidations, by sentence, composition, or otherwyse, shall within two yeeres after suche receipt, be truely imployed vpon the buyldynges & reparations, in respect whereof such money for dilapidations shalbe payde, on paine that euery person so receiuing, and not imploying as aforesayd, shal forfaite double as muche, as so shal be by hym receiued, and not imployed, the whiche forfaiture shalbe to the vse of the Queenes Maiestie, her heyres and successours.

Prouided alway and be it enacted, that no lease shalbe permitted to be made by force of this acte in reuersion, nor without reseruing
the accustomed yeerely rent at the least, nor without charging the lessee with the reparations, nor for longer terme then fourtie yeeres at the most: nor any houses shalbe permitted to be aliened, vnlesse that in recompence thereof, there shalbe afore, with, or presently after such alienation, good, lawful, & sufficient assuraunce made in fee simple absolutely to such Colledges, houses, bodyes politike or corporate, and their successours, of landes of as good value, and of as great yeerely value at the least, as so shalbe aliened: any statute to the contrary, notwithstandyng.

And forasmuche as all the same seuerall actes and statutes, and euery of them, do seeme good, beneficial, and needefull to be further continued for the weale and profite of this Realme: be it therefore nowe enacted by the Queenes most excellent Maiestie, with the assent of the Lordes Spirituall and Temporall, and the Commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the aucthoritie of the same, that the same seuerall actes and statutes, and euery of them, and all and euery article, clause, and sentences in them and euery of them conteyned, shall continue, be, and endure in full force and effect, vntyl the ende of the next Parliament.

div.head: An acte for the repeale of a statute made Anno, viij. of the Queenes Maiesties raigne, touching the towne of Shrewesburie. Chapter. xij.
div.p:
WHERE at the Parliament holden at Westminster the last day of September, in the eyght yeere of the raigne of our Soueraigne Lady the Queenes most excellent Maiestie, there was an acte made, entituled, An acte touchyng Drapers, Cotteners, & Frizers, in the Towne of Shrewesburie, in the Countie of Salop: and in the
same acte there is conteyned matter then supposed for the benefite of the said Towne of Shrewesburie, in aduauncing the corporation of Drapers, Cottoners, and Frizers of the sayd Towne. And it was thereby enacted, that from and after the feast of Easter then next ensuing, no maner person or persons whatsoeuer, inhabiting and dwelling within the saide Towne of Shrewesburie, or the liberties or franchises of ye same Towne, (other then suche as then had, or then after shoulde serue as apprentise in the occupation or science of Drapers, or then had benne, or thereafter shoulde be free of the sayde science or mysterie) should occupie, vse, exercise, or frequent the said trade, arte, mysterie, or science of buying of the said welsh cloth, or lining, cottens, fryzes, or plaines: nor haue any factour or dooer for him or them in the same, nor by any colour, engin, or fraude, buye any of the said fryzes, lininges, cottons, and plaines, vpon paine that euery person & persons inhabiting, as is aforesayde, and occupying, vsing, or exercising the said trade, arte, mysterie, occupation, or science of buying of welsh clothes and lininges. &c. and not aucthorised by the acte, shoulde lose & forfaite for euery peece of the said clothes bought .vi. s. viii. d

And where sithence the makyng of the sayde acte, experience hath plainely taught in the sayde Towne, that the sayd acte hath not only not brought the good effect that then was hoped and surmised, but also hath ben, and nowe is lykely, to be the very greatest cause of the impouerishing and vndooing of the poore artificers and other, at whose suite the saide acte was procured, for that there be nowe sithence the makyng of the sayd statute, much fewer persons to set them a woorke then before: and by restraynyng all other inhabitours of the sayd Towne of Shrewesbury, from the former lawfull trade euer heretofore vsed of buying of welshe clothes, fryzes, cottons, lyninges, and playnes (leauyng the same neuerthelesse free for all the subiectes of Englande without any restraynt, sauing for the sayde inhabitauntes of the Towne of Shrewesbury, and the liberties and franchises of the same Towne only) hath ben the euident occasion of great decay, not only to the saide Towne, and the liberties and franchises of the same, but also to a great and infinite number of poore people in Northwales, that is to say, in the Counties of Mountgomery, Denbigh, Merionneth, and also the Towne of Oswester, and the greatest part of the Countrey there aboutes, where the sayde Welshe clothes, fryzes, cottons, lyninges, and playnes are
made and solde, whiche were woont to be maynteyned and relieued by trade of makyng or woorkyng of the sayde fryzes, cottons, &c. contrary to the expectation that then was wrongfully conceiued.

Be it therfore, at the humble suite of the inhabitauntes of the sayde Towne, and also of the sayde artificers for whose benefite the sayde acte was supposed to be prouided, enacted, that the saide acte, and all the matter in the sayde acte conteyned, shall from hencefoorth be repealed and made voyde: any thyng in the sayde acte to the contrary notwithstandyng.

Prouided alwayes, that so muche of the sayde statute of the eyght yeere of our Soueraigne Ladye the Queenes Maiestie that nowe is, and euery article and braunche therein conteyned, as toucheth the present and ready payment of money to Sheremen, Cottoners, and Frizers, for their worke, & also as toucheth the restraint of suche as shall, or doo occupie or vse the trade of buying of frizes, cottons, or playnes, from the vse or exercise of the facultie of fryzing or cottoning, shall stande and be in force: any thing in this statute to the contrary, notwithstandyng.

div.head: An Acte for the annexing of Hexham and Hexhamshire to the Countie of Northumberlande. Chapter. xiij.
div.p:
WHERE for the space of diuers yeres nowe past, the Queene her highnesse, and her most noble and dearely beloued father king Henry the eyght, kyng Edwarde the sixth her highnesse brother, Queene Marie her late sister, as in the right of the imperiall crowne of this Realme of Englande, by reason of one exchaunge had, and passed betweene the sayd late kyng Henry the
eyght, and the late reuerend father Robert Archebishop of Yorke, in the yere of the most noble raigne of the sayd late king Henry, haue ben, and her maiestie yet is seased of and in the fraunchise and libertie of Hexham and Hexamshire, lying within the body and mydle of the Countie of Northumberlande, whiche sayde libertie & territorie, when it was in the handes of the sayde Archebishop, was commonly tearmed & named a Countie Palentyne, where in ryght or proofe there was none suche, yet by reason of that errour, euer since, and yet, there hath ben, and are diuers opinions, besides some question and doubtes, whether the sayd libertie and territorie of Hexham and Hexhamshire, should and ought to be part of the sayde Countie of Northumberland, or otherwyse exempted: and whether the dwellers & inhabitours there, shoulde and ought to be iustifiable, and aunswere to iustice as other of the sayde Countie of Northumberland are, and ought, or not: and the like question and doubt yet is, and remaineth. By reason wherof, not onely Plees of the Crowne, and suites betwixt partie & partie haue suffered continuall stayes, lets, and also haue had no ende of tryall, and besides, the most & greatest offendours to the crowne & their Countrey, haue, & dayly runne thither as vnto a sanctuarie, vpon hope and trust of refuge and safegarde thereby, to the great comfort and encouragement of many, the vilest & worste subiectes and offendours in all the North parties, and to the great offence of the almightie & most manifest hinderaunce of good execution of lawes and iustice. In and for due remedie and redresse of suche great enormities & apparante mischieues, may it therefore please the queene her Maiestie, that by her highnesse, the lordes spiritual and temporal, & the commons in this present hygh court of Parliament nowe assembled, that it may be enacted, manifested, and declared by aucthoritie of the same, that the sayd territorie, fraunchise, and libertie of Hexham and Hexhamshire, with the liberties of the same, may be, is, and shalbe from hencefoorth taken to be within, and part, parcell and member of the sayd Countie of Northumberlande. And that as wel the Plees of the Crowne, as also al suites betwixt partie and partie, may proceede, & haue their due ende and tryall within the sayde Countie of Northumberland, by and before the Shirife and Coroners of the sayde Shire, and also before the Iustices of peace, Iustices of gaole deliuerie, Iustices of assise, Nisi prius, Oyer and determiner, and other officers, and eche and euery of them, as the case shall require, and take effectes
as any of the like haue ben, or ought to be, which haue hapned, or shall hereafter happen within the sayd Countie of Northumberlande: and that from hencefoorth the Shirife and other officers of the Countie of Northumberland, for the time being, may haue full power and aucthoritie to execute his or their office, and al processes to him or them directed within Hexham and Hexhamshire, and liberties of the same, in as ample & large maner, as he or they may, should, or ought to do, within any other part of ye said Countie of Northumberlande, any graunt, priuilege, custome, vsage, libertie, or thing els whatsoeuer heretofore made, claymed, vsed, had, put in vre or execution, or enioyed, to the contrarie notwithstanding. Sauing to the Bayliffe of the liberties, or other officers of the sayde Towne of Hexham and Hexhamshire, or the liberties therof, al liberties and priuileges for executing of processe, returne of wryttes, and otherwyse, as they or any of them of right ought to haue before the makyng of this acte.

div.head: A Table of certayne actes passed, Anno. xiiij. Reginae Elizabethe, and not printed.

An act for the assurance of certaine lands, and tenementes, accordyng to the meanyng of syr Thomas and syr William Woodhouse, Knightes, for the benefite of certayne infantes.
An Act for the cōtinuaunce of the innyng of Plumsted marsh, in the Countie of Kent, beyng surrounded.
An Acte for the better & further assuraunce of certayne landes, and tenementes, to the mayntenaunce of the free Grammer scoole of Tunbridge, in the Countie of Kent.
